I want to prove the following technical statement for my work.

Screenshot-2024-09-20-at-3.57.12PM.png

The calculation can be done using Mathematica (or any other CAS). But I want to formally check this in Lean, or at least say that rigorous verification could be done in theory by using some software. Are there any established way of proving such statement? The functions are generic enough so the Jacobian is nonzero near the solution, approximated sufficiently close by linear approximations, etc.
I think these kinds of statements are can usually be proved using fixed-point theorems
I think Banach's fixed-point theorem might work here?
In this particular case I would first write A0 and B0 explicitly in terms of T using (1) and (3) and then focus on (2).
@Vincent Beffara That is a great idea for this case. Unfortunately I also have other cases involving more letters, in which such a technique would fail.

Daniel Weber said:

I think Banach's fixed-point theorem might work here?

This is a good strategy, but I need to figure out more details that is necessary. In general, we have some randomly defined F : R^3 -> R^3 and want to justify a solution (x0, y0, z0) such that F(x, y, z) = (0, 0, 0). Any fixpoint of G(x, y, z) = alpha*F(x, y, z) + (x, y, z) with any nonzero real alpha will give us a solution of F(x, y, z) = (0, 0, 0). So if we are lucky enough that there is some alpha such that G is a contraction map (near (x0, y0, z0)), then Banach fixed-point theorem could work. But it's possible that such alpha won't exist, and I need to do this for multiple F's.

After writing this, I realized I can let alpha be the linear transformation -DF(x0, y0, z0)^{-1} (or its close approximation) so that the derivative of G is close enough to zero near (x0, y0, z0). This will work for me I guess.
Jineon Baek has marked this topic as resolved.
